abstract: In the throes of a divorce, Harry Hurt II is cleaning out and moving on and checking the Dumpster, too.
snippet: In the throes of a divorce, Harry Hurt II is cleaning out and moving on and checking the Dumpster, too.
lead_paragraph: I BURST out the back door of Chateau Bow Wow, a k a the Doghouse, intent on salvaging the last few remnants of an almost-past life by Dumpster-diving in my own driveway. It looked to be a fine day for such an otherwise inauspicious executive pursuit. The late October air was crisper than an ice cream bar, and a deck of flat white clouds stretched across the sky from Sag Harbor, N.Y., to beyond forever.

headline.main: After a Life-Altering Event, Cleaning Out and Moving On
headline.print_headline: After a Life-Altering Event, Cleaning Out and Moving On

abstract: Avon’s chairwoman and chief executive, Andrea Jung, discusses how the company’s direct-selling model can improve the lives of women in developing countries.
snippet: Avon’s chairwoman and chief executive, Andrea Jung, discusses how the company’s direct-selling model can improve the lives of women in developing countries.
lead_paragraph: THE cosmetic company Avon Products traces its roots to the horse and buggy days of the late 19th century, when sales representatives sold perfume door-to-door, often to women who lived far from big department stores. This American frontier model has translated well to countries like Brazil and China, where large populations are dispersed across a vast countryside. Today, more than two-thirds of Avon’s sales are outside the United States.

headline.main: Selling Beauty on a Global Scale
headline.print_headline: Selling Beauty on a Global Scale

abstract: Scientists said the F.D.A. had produced a flawed safety assessment of a chemical used for decades in baby bottles and food storage containers.
snippet: Scientists said the F.D.A. had produced a flawed safety assessment of a chemical used for decades in baby bottles and food storage containers.
lead_paragraph: Scientists advising the Food and Drug Administration said the agency had produced a flawed safety assessment of a chemical used for decades in baby bottles and food storage containers. A panel of doctors and researchers said the F.D.A. had failed to provide enough evidence that the chemical, bisphenol-A, or BPA, was not a risk to the public. The panel said more research was needed. BPA, used to stiffen plastic and line metal cans, has been linked in some research to diabetes and developmental changes in children.

headline.main: Panel Criticizes F.D.A. Study of Chemical

lead_paragraph: MALCOLM GLADWELL has a rare ability: he can transform academic research into engaging fables spotlighting real people. His new book, “Outliers: The Story of Success” (Little, Brown, $27.99), with its entertaining psychology and sociology, is catchy and beautifully written. lead_paragraph: It’s been widely suspected that applications to M.B.A. programs are inversely correlated to the state of the economy, with several schools expecting record numbers for the class of 2011. The theory goes like this: the opportunity costs of going back to school — the forgone salary, bonuses, promotions, etc. — are much lower during the bad times. Therefore, returning to school becomes a relative bargain, positioning students for greater success when the economy recovers (ideally before graduation).

headline.main: Taking Stock of Life’s Options While at Business School

abstract: Chile announced that it would set aside more than $1 billion in a stimulus plan to help middle-income families and smaller businesses survive the global financial crisis.
snippet: Chile announced that it would set aside more than $1 billion in a stimulus plan to help middle-income families and smaller businesses survive the global financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Chile announced that it would set aside more than $1 billion in a stimulus plan to help middle-income families and smaller businesses survive the global financial crisis. President Michelle Bachelet said $500 million would enable Chile’s state-owned BancoEstado to increase credit for qualifying businesses. The other half will subsidize home buying by middle-income families, creating more jobs in the construction industry. Chile’s finance minister, Andrés Velasco, said the country’s economy was solid enough to survive “this huge international storm.”

headline.main: Chile: $1 Billion Stimulus Plan Announced
headline.print_headline: Chile: $1 Billion Stimulus Plan Announced

abstract: BMW said that profit for the third quarter dropped 63 percent as the global economic turmoil made consumers more reluctant to buy its sports and luxury cars.
snippet: BMW said that profit for the third quarter dropped 63 percent as the global economic turmoil made consumers more reluctant to buy its sports and luxury cars.
lead_paragraph: BMW said that profit for the third quarter dropped 63 percent as the global economic turmoil made consumers more reluctant to buy its sports and luxury cars. The company, based in Munich, said net profit for the July-September period fell to 298 million euros ($375.5 million), from 803 million euros a year ago. Sales for the quarter fell 9 percent, to 12.6 billion euros ($16 billion), from 14 billion euros in the quarter a year ago. The company also said the financial crisis made it impossible to provide a forecast for the rest of the year. In North America, the company sold 6 percent fewer cars than last year, but the company said it had “sharp growth” in central and Eastern Europe as well as in Latin America and Asia.

headline.main: Germany: Profit Falls at BMW

abstract: The credit crisis is affecting the cost — and the ability — of importers to find trade finance.

lead_paragraph: Trade finance  the grease of the world economy  used to be easy to find. It’s now so expensive that it threatens to halt global commerce. The Baltic Dry Index, a barometer of world trade that measures shipping rates, is down 93 percent from its peak in May to the lowest in nine years. Shippers were the first to be hit by the credit crisis, but importers, who now have to borrow at prohibitive rates, are also feeling the pain.

abstract: That’s what I kept thinking as I watched Barack Obama’s first post-election press conference as he confronted the economic crisis as president-elect rather than presidential candidate. There was certainly something calming about his crisp responses, his clear sense of competence, and his obvious confidence. He also had an easy banter with the press that went down easily. Franklin Roosevelt had all of those qualities. But Roosevelt was also a beacon of hope and inspiration during the dark days of the Depression, and that is what this country desperately needs now, as it tries to claw its way out of this awful recession and a financial crisis that is far from over.

abstract: Expenses tied to jet fuel contracts and currency exchange led to the loss after analysts had expected a profit.
snippet: Expenses tied to jet fuel contracts and currency exchange led to the loss after analysts had expected a profit.
lead_paragraph: Air Canada, the country’s largest carrier, posted a third-quarter loss because of expenses tied to jet fuel contracts and currency exchange after analysts had expected a profit. The shares fell the most in four months. The net loss was 132 million Canadian dollars ($111 million) compared with net income of 273 million Canadian dollars a year earlier, the airline, which is based in Montreal, said in a statement. Revenue rose 4.1 percent, to 3.08 billion Canadian dollars. Shares fell 16 percent on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Air Canada has said it will trim as many as 2,000 jobs, shrink United States seating capacity and pare routes to Europe and Asia after a first-half loss of $166 million Canadian dollars.

headline.main: Fuel Contracts Contribute to Loss for Air Canada

lead_paragraph: Procter & Gamble said the United States Patent and Trademark Office upheld its patent used for a Folgers-brand plastic coffee container. The ruling clears a hurdle for P.& G.’s patent-infringement lawsuit against Kraft Foods, claiming Maxwell House coffee packaging violates its property. P.& G. began selling Folgers in a plastic container in 2003, saying the tubs better preserved freshness and helped increase sales. A Kraft spokeswoman described the ruling as procedural and said the company did not infringe valid patents.

headline.main: Patent Office Backs P.&G. in Infringement Case

abstract: Apple’s new executive may have violated an agreement with his former employer, I.B.M., a New York judge ruled.
snippet: Apple’s new executive may have violated an agreement with his former employer, I.B.M., a New York judge ruled.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s new executive in charge of iPods and iPhones must stop work immediately because he may have violated an agreement with his former employer, I.B.M., a New York judge ruled. The executive, Mark Papermaster, left for Apple last month. I.B.M. sued him, saying the move violated an employment contract in which he agreed not to work for a competitor within a year of leaving his job. Mr. Papermaster “will immediately cease his employment with Apple Inc. until further order of this court,” Kenneth Karas, a United States District Court judge in White Plains, said. He scheduled a hearing for Nov. 18.

headline.main: Judge Says Apple Executive Must Cease Working

abstract: Why do we spend hundreds of dollars on equipment to film and store our pictures and videos, without any assurance that anyone will ever want to view them?
snippet: Why do we spend hundreds of dollars on equipment to film and store our pictures and videos, without any assurance that anyone will ever want to view them?
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, writing about Apple's new flagship laptop, the MacBook, I noted with dismay that Apple appears intent on eliminating the FireWire jack. FireWire is a connector, originally developed and promoted by Apple itself, that lets you import video from a tape camcorder for easy editing. It was a cornerstone of Apple's "anyone can edit video" revolution.

headline.main: Why We Shoot Home Videos

abstract: As a group, economists failed to see this recession coming. Should we now trust their forecast that it will be over by the middle of 2009?
snippet: As a group, economists failed to see this recession coming. Should we now trust their forecast that it will be over by the middle of 2009?
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal reports today that its poll of economists showed a consensus that the recession would end by mid-2009. They think that the current quarter will be down sharply, at a 3 percent annual rate, and that there will be a lesser decline in the first quarter of 2009. The second quarter is expected to be up at an annual rate of 0.3 percent, and solid growth will be back in the second half of the year.

headline.main: They Missed the Start; Now They See the End

lead_paragraph: Shares of Abercrombie & Fitch fell the most in eight years after the teen-apparel retailer cut its profit forecast as shoppers held off on buying upscale jeans. Abercrombie reduced its annual earnings forecast by a third after posting its first quarterly sales drop in seven years. Third-quarter net income decreased 46 percent to $63.9 million, or 72 cents a share, from $117.6 million, or $1.29, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue in the three months that ended Nov. 1 dropped 8 percent to $896.3 million. Shares fell nearly 21 percent, to $17.79.

Together, the two rounds of job cuts represent 3,000 employees, or about 7 percent of the company’s 44,400-member work force, a Fidelity spokeswoman said. The global market sell-off has reduced Fidelity’s assets under management this year by about 13 percent, to $1.4 trillion from $1.6 trillion through Sept. 30.

headline.main: Fidelity Layoffs to Total 3,000 Workers

abstract: Maybe it was the tombstone that did it. Even as Wall Street burned, Silicon Valley seemed strangely sanguine. A month later, venture capital firms are slashing investments and counseling portfolio companies to cut jobs. Sequoia’s warning may reflect the technology industry’s woes, but it’s more notable for what it says about venture capital.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the tombstone that did it. Even as Wall Street burned, Silicon Valley seemed strangely sanguine. Then a PowerPoint presentation from Sequoia Capital prophesying Armageddon – featuring an “R.I.P. Good Times” headstone – made the rounds. A month later, venture capital firms are slashing investments and counseling portfolio companies to cut jobs. Sequoia’s warning may reflect the technology industry’s woes, but it’s more notable for what it says about venture capital.

headline.main: From the Valley Comes a Warning

abstract: Jim Grosfeld, the former chief executive of Pulte Homes, and a board member at BlackRock, the investment firm, has become one of my regular correspondents. Along with a small handful of others, he has spent much of his time recently trying to come up with ideas to help homeowners avoid foreclosures, which remains the country’s most pressing economic problem. Until the rate of foreclosures slows, the crisis simply will not come to an end (though you would never know that from the government’s appalling lack of urgency). Continued foreclosures hurt housing prices for everyone — and that, in turn, will mean continued multi-billion write-downs on Wall Street, further jeopardizing the financial system.

abstract: Tiger Brands, South Africa’s largest food company, offered 8 billion rand ($787 million) for AVI, its main rival.
snippet: Tiger Brands, South Africa’s largest food company, offered 8 billion rand ($787 million) for AVI, its main rival.
lead_paragraph: Tiger Brands, South Africa’s largest food company, offered 8 billion rand ($787 million) for AVI, its main rival. The cash-and-stock bid was about 62 percent more than AVI’s closing price of 14.80 rand on Nov. 14, Tiger said in a statement. AVI, which rejected the proposal, gained 32 percent in trading in Johannesburg. The company’s strategy is to dominate its local market and expand into East Africa and West Africa. AVI said the offer was the third made by Tiger since Oct. 8. The board “is of the view that the potential offers were not in the best interests of AVI or its shareholders,” the company said in a stock exchange statement. AVI is “unconvinced as to the commercial merits as set out by Tiger Brands.” Tiger is now canvassing AVI’s shareholders for approval, its chief executive, Peter Matlare, said.

headline.main: South Africa: Rival Bids Again to Buy Food Company
headline.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA: RIVAL BIDS AGAIN TO BUY FOOD COMPANY

abstract: Chinese officials signed an agreement with the European Union, promising to strengthen the exchange of information over faulty products.
snippet: Chinese officials signed an agreement with the European Union, promising to strengthen the exchange of information over faulty products.
lead_paragraph: Chinese officials signed an agreement with the European Union, promising to strengthen the exchange of information over faulty products, improve the ability to trace dangerous goods and increase cooperation in recalling products. Meglena Kuneva, the European consumer protection commissioner, said the accord provided for “more transparency, better monitoring and new possibilities for joint surveillance.” The accord coincided with the release of figures showing a significant rise in dangerous goods from China entering the European market. About 85 percent of toys on the European market are made in China. At the meeting, the United States also agreed to work more closely with the European Union on converging regulatory standards and exchanging information. Chinese officials say they support this goal, because it is difficult to meet two different sets of export standards.

headline.main: Belgium: China Signs Product Safety Accord
headline.print_headline: BELGIUM: CHINA SIGNS PRODUCT SAFETY ACCORD

abstract: The Australian brewer Lion Nathan made a hostile bid of 7.6 billion Australian dollars ($4.91 billion), for the soft drinks distributor Coca-Cola Amatil.
snippet: The Australian brewer Lion Nathan made a hostile bid of 7.6 billion Australian dollars ($4.91 billion), for the soft drinks distributor Coca-Cola Amatil.
lead_paragraph: The Australian brewer Lion Nathan made a hostile bid of 7.6 billion Australian dollars ($4.91 billion), for the soft drinks distributor Coca-Cola Amatil. The bid, a cash and stock proposal, values Coca-Cola Amatil at 10.35 dollars a share, a 25 percent premium over the closing price Friday. If successful, the acquisition would give Lion Nathan a 60 percent share in Australia’s soft-drink market, which is valued at 10.3 billion dollars, Reuters reported. Coca-Cola Amatil said the offer contained “a number of material deficiencies” and was “materially below recent multiples paid for domestic and international beverage companies.” It said the deal was unlikely to be supported by Coca-Cola of Atlanta, which owns 30 percent of Coca-Cola Amatil, its Australian distributor. Kirin Brewery, the Japanese beer maker, holds a 46 percent stake in Lion Nathan. Lion Nathan said the deal would create the largest beverages company in Australia and New Zealand, with diversified holdings in soft drinks, beer, wine and spirits. Coca-Cola Amatil recently expanded into alcohol by starting a joint venture with SAB Miller, selling Peroni Nastro Azzurro and Miller Genuine Draft.

headline.main: Australia: Hostile Bid Made for Coca-Cola Unit
headline.print_headline: AUSTRALIA: HOSTILE BID MADE FOR COCA-COLA UNIT

abstract: A little preventive maintenance on the computer can help stop lurking system problems like low disk space or damaged drivers from becoming real headaches.
snippet: A little preventive maintenance on the computer can help stop lurking system problems like low disk space or damaged drivers from becoming real headaches.
lead_paragraph: Just as a flu shot can help avoid misery later in the season, a little preventive maintenance on the computer can help stop lurking system problems like low disk space or damaged drivers from becoming real headaches. Windows Vista can generate its own diagnostic System Health Report that points out potential problems. To receive the report, type “Performance” (without the quotation marks) in the search bar on the Vista Start menu and click on Performance and Information Tools. Click on the Advanced Tools item and then on Generate a System Health Report. After about a minute of data gathering, Windows Vista gives the full report on screen.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Monitoring the Health of Your Computer

lead_paragraph: The new Walgreens sign going live in Times Square Thursday is not the largest LED-based sign in the world, but its developers believe that it is the most complex, both in terms of its construction and operation. Rising 340 feet high, the 17,000-square-foot sign wraps most of the facade of the One Times Square building. It combines a series of diagonal LED panels, plus 13 60-inch plasma displays to create a single moving image with 20 times the resolution of standard HDTV.

abstract: VEM Vermögensverwaltung, the investment unit of the Merckle family of Germany, won a two-week extension to secure bank financing after a short squeeze on Volkswagen shares.
snippet: VEM Vermögensverwaltung, the investment unit of the Merckle family of Germany, won a two-week extension to secure bank financing after a short squeeze on Volkswagen shares.
lead_paragraph: VEM Vermögensverwaltung, the investment unit of the Merckle family of Germany, won a two-week extension to secure bank financing after a short squeeze on Volkswagen shares and the plunging value of HeidelbergCement led to a “liquidity shortage.” The company can now continue negotiations on a bridge loan, VEM said. VEM became caught in a so-called short squeeze after betting that Volkswagen’s stock would fall. Porsche announced on Oct. 26 that it planned to increase its stake in Volkswagen to 75 percent. That led to a race by short-sellers to buy from a shrinking pool of stock, causing Volkswagen shares to surge more than fourfold in two days.

headline.main: Germany: Merckles Get an Extension
headline.print_headline: GERMANY: MERCKLES GET AN EXTENSION

lead_paragraph: Marsh & McLennan, an insurance broker, cleared the way to raise $500 million in a stock sale to finance acquisitions. The broker may sell 22.6 million shares to help buy “businesses, assets or securities,” Marsh & McLennan, which is based in New York, said in a regulatory filing. Marsh & McLennan has “always said we will seek attractively priced acquisitions if they complement our existing businesses,” a spokeswoman, Laura Cora, said. The company is the best-performing stock tracked by the KBW Insurance Index this year, sliding 9.6 percent compared with the 63 percent decline of the whole index.

lead_paragraph: The American International Group, the insurer bailed out by the federal government, will complete the sale of its airplane-leasing arm, the International Lease Finance Corporation, to a group of investors including the unit’s management by early next year, an executive said. “Early next year, we will consummate the closing,” Steven Udvar-Hazy, left, the founder and chief executive officer of the unit, known as I.L.F.C., said in an interview. “One thing is to reach a deal. It’s another to close the deal.” Authorities decided to sell all units that are not related to A.I.G.’s insurance business after the federal government took a controlling stake in exchange for capitalizing A.I.G., Mr. Udvar-Hazy said.

abstract: I was on Bill Moyers Journal on Friday–an enjoyable experience, by the way–and the subject was what the events of this past week told us about the state of the financial crisis. We talked about Citigroup, about the various conflicting statements coming out of the mouth of the Treasury Secretary, Henry Paulson, and about the painful collapse of stock prices. But somewhat to my surprise, we didn’t talk much about the trip to Washington by the chief executives of the Big Three automakers. Given everything that happened this past week, that news tended to get short shrift.

abstract: People using both Google Calendar and Gmail can add a small window into Google Calendar right in the main Gmail screen, which makes planning activities by e-mail even easier.
snippet: People using both Google Calendar and Gmail can add a small window into Google Calendar right in the main Gmail screen, which makes planning activities by e-mail even easier.
lead_paragraph: People using both Google Calendar and Gmail can add a small window into Google Calendar right in the main Gmail screen  which makes planning activities by e-mail even easier. To add the calendar, log into your Gmail account on the Web and click the settings link at the top of the page. Click the Google Labs tab, scroll down the page to Google Calendar Gadget and click on the Enable button. Click the Save Changes button at the bottom of the page to return to the main Gmail window, where a small version of Google Calendar now appears at the left. Click the Add button at the bottom of the Calendar gadget to quickly schedule new events.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: A Faster Way to Update Google Calendar

abstract: In ad campaigns, most wristwatches are frozen with their hands at 10 and 2, to “frame the brand and logo.”
snippet: In ad campaigns, most wristwatches are frozen with their hands at 10 and 2, to “frame the brand and logo.”
lead_paragraph: THE Ulysse Nardin wristwatch in an ad in the most recent Sunday edition of The New York Times is unlike 22 of the 24 watches featured in that issue’s ads, but chances are that didn’t register with most readers. For horologists, however, whose scrutiny of watches tends toward the Talmudic, it’s a lapel grabber: all the other watches  from brands like Rolex, TAG Heuer and Gucci  are set at 10:10, but Ulysse Nardin’s watch is set at 8:19. (The only other exception is an Oris wristwatch, one of four featured in an ad by the retailer Tourneau, which is set at 8:03.)

headline.main: Why Time Stands Still for Watchmakers

abstract: A Chicago-based truck dealership is seeing the effects of the credit crisis far more clearly than most policy makers.
snippet: A Chicago-based truck dealership is seeing the effects of the credit crisis far more clearly than most policy makers.
lead_paragraph: When you live and work in New York, it is easy to succumb to the fallacy that the financial crisis is all about us. It’s about giant, New York-based institutions failing or coming close to failing. It’s about high-stakes weekends in the offices of the New York Federal Reserve. It’s about credit-default swaps and mortgage-backed securities and the wild swings of the New York stock exchange. It’s about Jamie Dimon and Richard Fuld.

headline.main: Out of the Spotlight, an Industry Copes With Crisis
headline.print_headline: Crisis Born On Wall St. Hits Road

abstract: A look at how Navistar, the country’s last remaining independent truck maker, is weathering the financial crisis.
snippet: A look at how Navistar, the country’s last remaining independent truck maker, is weathering the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: My goal this week was to get out of New York and Washington and see how the financial crisis was affecting an old-line middle American company. The company I chose to focus on — not quite randomly, but pretty close — was Navistar, the country’s last remaining independent truck maker. As I discovered, Navistar itself is well-positioned to weather the storm, thanks in part of having obtained some low-cost financing that will carry it through 2012. But it’s customers — everyone from independent truck drivers to big trucking companies — are being hit hard by the crisis. They are the subject of this week’s column.

headline.main: The Trucking Business Takes a Hit

lead_paragraph: “Rosie Live,” NBC’s variety show special with Rosie O’Donnell, attracted only modest interest in the ratings on the night before Thanksgiving, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The show earned just 5 million viewers and a third place finish in the 8 p.m. hour behind Fox’s “Bones” (9.8 million) and CBS’s comedy block of “The New Adventures of Old Christine” (7.6 million) and “Gary Unmarried” (7.7 million).

abstract: Eli Lilly withdrew its application for approval of the antidepressant Cymbalta as a treatment for chronic pain, after regulators questioned whether the drug was shown to work for that purpose.
snippet: Eli Lilly withdrew its application for approval of the antidepressant Cymbalta as a treatment for chronic pain, after regulators questioned whether the drug was shown to work for that purpose.
lead_paragraph: Eli Lilly withdrew its application for approval of the antidepressant Cymbalta as a treatment for chronic pain, after regulators questioned whether the drug was shown to work for that purpose. The company said it would resubmit the application during the first half of next year with more data. Lilly had applied to the Food and Drug Administration this year for approval of Cymbalta to manage chronic pain. The drug already is cleared for anxiety, depression, nerve pain from diabetes and a painful condition called Fibromyalgia. The withdrawal doesn’t affect those uses, the company said.

headline.main: Drug Company Withdraws Application
headline.print_headline: Drug Company Withdraws Application

abstract: Goldman Sachs Group won approval for a New York State banking license to transform into a bank holding company and take deposits.
snippet: Goldman Sachs Group won approval for a New York State banking license to transform into a bank holding company and take deposits.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs Group won approval for a New York State banking license to transform into a bank holding company and take deposits. Goldman Sachs Bank USA will have its headquarters in New York City, the New York State Banking Department said Friday in a statement. Goldman was one of nine major United States banks that received a total of $125 billion under the government’s $700 billion rescue plan for the financial industry. Goldman Sachs’s Utah-based industrial loan company will merge into its New York-state chartered trust company, Goldman Sachs Trust Company, which will in turn become a full-service New York bank with trust powers.

headline.main: Goldman Sachs Gets N.Y. Banking License
headline.print_headline: Goldman Sachs Gets N.Y. Banking License

abstract: The industrial chemical melamine is safe in baby formula in small amounts, the Food and Drug Administration said.
snippet: The industrial chemical melamine is safe in baby formula in small amounts, the Food and Drug Administration said.
lead_paragraph: The industrial chemical melamine is safe in baby formula in small amounts, the Food and Drug Administration said. The F.D.A. had said before finding the contamination that melamine might be harmful in infant formula in any amount. The F.D.A. began barring Chinese milk products from entering the country this month after melamine-tainted milk sickened more than 50,000 children in China since September. Members of Congress and consumer groups criticized the agency this week for not publicly disclosing that a formula made in the United States had also tested positive for “trace” amounts of melamine, a chemical used in plastics and fertilizer. The liquid form of Good Start Supreme infant formula with iron, by Nestlé, tested positive for melamine in as much as 0.14 parts per million, said Stephen Sundlof, director of the agency’s Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition.

headline.main: F.D.A. Allows Trace Amounts of Chemical in Formula
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Allows Trace Amounts of Chemical In Formula
